content.description: Hike and scramble up a mix of scree and loose rock roughly along/below the ridge until beneath the obvious chute just east of the western-most prominence. Stay on the most traveled line as that has the least choss, step carefully. Ascend up the chute on increasingly steep and exposed, but better cleaned rock; try not to pull on anything harder than necessary. Top out of the chute and walk up to the summit.
content.protection: No protection to speak of on the 4th class section, a few options for slinging horns or trees once at the top.
content.location: At the end of the Pinnacle Saddle Trail, take the eastern path approximately 1/4 mile to a fork, then head up the ridge via the left option.

content.description:
Standard alpine ridge climb with blocky features and climbing ranging in difficulty from class 4 to 5.5. Loose rock and scree is a serious concern on this route.

Pitch 1: Scramble up mostly 4 class terrain to a belay ledge with a large dead tree.

Pitch 2: Climb blocky terrain up to 5.5 to an obvious belay bench which features a rappel anchor going down the south face. An old piton can be clipped about a quarter of the way up the route. A traverse about half way up the pitch offers some excitement and exposure.

Pitch 3: Continue to the summit on mostly mellow terrain. This pitch is more of a walk up and could be done unroped or simul-climb if comfortable with the terrain. Note if pitching this out, a 60 meter rope may not make it to the true summit depending on where you set up the anchor, but the terrain is so mellow it shouldn't be an issue.
content.protection: 5 to 8 double runners, 2 to 4 cams in the small to mid range (e.g. 0.4,  0.75, etc.), a few nuts may also be useful.
content.location: From the Castle/Pinnacle col (46.7571, -121.7305) take the obvious east ridge up Pinnacle.
